awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Behavior and energetics of parenting
awd_abstract_narration:
Cooperative infant care in which multiple individuals contribute to caring for a single offspring is thought to have played a key role in human evolution by reducing the energy mothers need to invest in their offspring. It can be challenging to disentangle the relationship between energetic costs and benefits of care provided by multiple individuals, and the study of this question can benefit from the examination of other species with similar forms of cooperative infant care. The simplest form, where infants receive care from only their mother and father, is called biparental care. This Doctoral Dissertation Research project measures energy expenditure related to infant care in primate species with biparental cooperative infant care. Behavioral data, movement data, and metabolic measurements of energy use during infant care are combined from wild and captive populations to investigate how these monkeys distribute the energetic costs of childcare responsibilities. The project supports long-term research and scientists at a field station and produces short bilingual videos to disseminate results.

To quantify the relative investment of male and female parents in the care of their infants, this research combines behavioral data from both coppery titi monkeys with activity and energetics data. Coppery titi monkey mothers and fathers each specialize in some caring tasks: mothers nurse and fathers carry the infant. However, the extent of sex-based specialization for other caring behaviors, such as grooming and tolerated food theft remains unknown as does the energetic burden of these behaviors and any compensatory changes in the parents’ activity. Activity data will be collected throughout the entire period of infant care , andallows inferences about the energetic investment parents make during infant care to be made on both behavioral and physiological bases since the measures of energy use will be in the context of behavior and activity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated the relative contributions of biparental, pair-bonded male and female titi monkeys (Plecturocebus cupreus) to the care of their infants. By integrating behavioral and energetic data, it investigated the simplest form of cooperative breeding: biparental care (i.e., infant care from the mother is only modified by the care of one other individual: the father). In doing so, it contributes to our understanding of more complex forms of cooperative breeding, a reproductive strategy central to understanding human evolution.

Between September 2022 and July 2024, we studied ten wild-born infant titi monkeys at Estación Biológica Quebrada Blanco near Iquitos, Peru, and six captive-born infant titi monkeys at the California National Primate Research Center in Davis, CA. Our goal was to document how the fathers and mothers cared for the infants differently. We also measured their movements (using accelerometers), and the total energetic expenditure (using doubly labeled water) of captive titi monkeys in two different reproductive states. We compared activity and energetics of parents who were actively caring for their infant with adult titis without any dependent infants. We sought to examine the extent to which mothers and fathers have specialized roles in infant care, as predicted by the Task Specialization Hypothesis for the evolutionary stability of biparental care. We also wanted to quantify the differences in energy expenditure during infant care between the parents, and between caring and non-caring individuals using the Constrained Total Energy Expenditure (TEE) paradigm.

Analysis is ongoing, but preliminary results indicate that males and females do not have substantially overlapping roles in infant care. After birth, titi monkey mothers nurse their infants, but otherwise rarely interact with them. Conversely, just days after birth the adult males (presumably the fathers in the wild monkeys and certainly the fathers in the captive ones) are carrying the infants, grooming them, inspecting them, and allowing them to steal food when they are transitioning to solid foods. Ongoing analyses are assessing the energetic expenditure of parents in captivity and are relating energic expenditure with compensatory changes in movement. Findings of sex-differences in energic expenditure during infant care, when combined with comparable performance of infant care behaviors among our captive and wild monkeys, will allow us to disentangle the relative contributions of titi monkey parents to their successful reproduction.
